awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Dimension Reduction Methods for Estimating Economic Models with Panel Data
awd_abstract_narration:
A vast empirical literature has demonstrated that firms, workers, schools, or banks differ from each other, and that accounting for agent heterogeneity in economic models is often key for accurate quantitative predictions. This project develops new techniques to capture relevant sources of heterogeneity which are not directly observed in the data, but can be inferred using repeated observations of individual choices or other outcomes. Flexibly modeling unobserved differences between agents with individual-specific parameters raises important challenges in terms of computation and statistical inference. The approach developed in this project is based on dimension reduction methods whereby heterogeneous agents are grouped into a small number of types.   
 
Discrete methods provide a way to reduce the dimensionality of heterogeneity. This may be advantageous for both computational and statistical reasons. However, existing methods such as finite mixtures face computational challenges, and they are mostly studied under the strong assumption that heterogeneity is discrete in the population. The investigators broaden the scope of discrete methods, by developing computationally tractable two-step estimators and studying their properties in the absence of such substantive assumptions. This research also illustrates the usefulness of these methods in applications, particularly in structural models where allowing for unobserved heterogeneity raises important challenges, and in models with two-sided heterogeneity.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The world is heterogeneous: some countries are organized in democracies while others are ruled in autocracy, some firms are able to produce more than others are, and some workers receive stratospheric salaries while others only make the minimum wage. The world is also heterogeneous in “unobservable ways”. For example, workers in the same occupation might receive different salaries despite similar educational attainments and similar number of years of experience.

Dealing with heterogeneity in empirical work, both observed and unobserved, is critical: not accounting for it can lead to wrong predictions of counterfactual policies, but modeling it in naïve ways often result in over parametrization, and consequently, statistically imprecise answers to the question under study. In my research, I explore the usefulness of a dimension reduction methods used in machine learning to incorporate heterogeneity in parsimonious ways in a variety of contexts.

Together with my collaborators, Stephane Bonhomme and Thibaut Lamadon, in this project we study panel data estimators based on a discretization of unobserved heterogeneity using k-means clustering. K-means clustering is a statistical tool that groups units of observation into clusters, such that individuals that are more similar are together.

Our methods are useful in a wide set of contexts. For instance, our methodology allow us to learn about the nature of inequality in wages.  In our published paper “A Distributional Framework for Matched Employer Employee”, we propose a framework to identify and estimate earnings distributions and worker composition using a special dataset, matched panel data, that follows workers and the firms where they work over time. In this framework, we allow for general forms of complementarities between worker and firms types, which is a crucial quantity to quantify the gains from reallocation of workers to firms. The identification relies on workers that have worked in multiple firms. We use discretization of the firm’s unobserved heterogeneity as a regularization device to alleviate the “limited mobility bias” typical of matched employer employee dataset. In this way, we gain precision and we conclude that the great bulk of the inequality of wages is due to workers having different skills, and not firms paying different wages to similar workers. In addition, we also find that better workers tend to work for better firms, further contributing to the wide dispersion of wages.


Last Modified: 11/17/2022
Modified by: Elena Manresa
